summary_markdown:
# About Imagine Pediatrics

Imagine Pediatrics is a healthcare company based in Nashville, founded in 2022 by Taylor Beery, Zeena Johar, Meghan Haycraft, and Alison Curfman. The company specializes in providing virtual healthcare services specifically for children with complex medical conditions. Their services include 24/7 virtual and in-home pediatric care, focusing on integrated medical, behavioral, and social care. Imagine Pediatrics aims to address the fragmented healthcare system that children with special health care needs (CSHCN) often face by offering comprehensive support that includes technology-enabled care coordination and caregiver support [(Tracxn, 2023-10-11)](https://tracxn.com/d/companies/imagine-pediatrics/__suYLZqgbd3LGJm7PXqubGnwtYxfMmJMAOKDXyYnbYHQ).

The company operates on a B2C model, primarily serving children and their families. As of the latest reports, Imagine Pediatrics has raised a total of $37.6 million in funding, with its most recent Series C round completed on February 27, 2025. The company has achieved significant milestones, including serving over 30,000 patients across three states and reducing the Medical Cost Ratio by over 10% [(Tracxn, 2023-10-11)](https://tracxn.com/d/companies/imagine-pediatrics/__suYLZqgbd3LGJm7PXqubGnwtYxfMmJMAOKDXyYnbYHQ).

Imagine Pediatrics is positioned within a competitive landscape, ranked 27th among 107 active competitors, including companies like Teladoc and Plushcare. Despite the competition, the company differentiates itself through its focus on children with complex medical needs and its commitment to caregiver engagement [(Tracxn, 2023-10-11)](https://tracxn.com/d/companies/imagine-pediatrics/__suYLZqgbd3LGJm7PXqubGnwtYxfMmJMAOKDXyYnbYHQ).

# Key Personnel

- **Taylor Beery**: Co-founder of Imagine Pediatrics. Beery emphasizes the importance of engaged caregivers in the healthcare system and advocates for policies that recognize caregiving as essential work [(Beery & Curfman, 2025-01-24)](https://www.imaginepediatrics.org/white-paper/the-value-of-engaged-caregivers-in-improving-outcomes-for-children-with-special-health-care-needs/).

- **Alison Curfman**: Co-founder of Imagine Pediatrics. Curfman, along with Beery, supports innovative care models that promote caregiver engagement [(Beery & Curfman, 2025-01-24)](https://www.imaginepediatrics.org/white-paper/the-value-of-engaged-caregivers-in-improving-outcomes-for-children-with-special-health-care-needs/).

# News

## Funding and Financials

Imagine Pediatrics has successfully raised $37.6 million in funding, with Oak HC/FT as its institutional investor. The company is currently in the Series C stage, indicating strong investor interest in its innovative approach to pediatric care [(Tracxn, 2023-10-11)](https://tracxn.com/d/companies/imagine-pediatrics/__suYLZqgbd3LGJm7PXqubGnwtYxfMmJMAOKDXyYnbYHQ).

## Market Position and Competitors

Imagine Pediatrics operates in a competitive market with 107 active competitors. Its primary competitors include Teladoc, Plushcare, and Firefly Health. Despite the competition, Imagine Pediatrics differentiates itself through its focus on children with complex medical needs and its commitment to caregiver engagement [(Tracxn, 2023-10-11)](https://tracxn.com/d/companies/imagine-pediatrics/__suYLZqgbd3LGJm7PXqubGnwtYxfMmJMAOKDXyYnbYHQ).

## Achievements

The company has achieved significant milestones, including:

- Serving over 30,000 patients across three states.
- Achieving a 10%+ reduction in Medical Cost Ratio.
- Receiving an 87+ Net Promoter Score from patients and caregivers.
- Preventing over 5,000 emergency and urgent care visits through timely primary interventions [(Beery & Curfman, 2025-01-24)](https://www.imaginepediatrics.org/white-paper/the-value-of-engaged-caregivers-in-improving-outcomes-for-children-with-special-health-care-needs/).

## Conclusion

Imagine Pediatrics is positioned as a leader in the virtual healthcare space for children with special health care needs. With a strong funding base, innovative care model, and a commitment to caregiver engagement, the company is well-equipped to address the challenges faced by CSHCN and their families. As it continues to grow, prospective candidates and investors may find significant opportunities in its mission to transform pediatric care.

webpage_result.summary_markdown:
# Imagine Pediatrics Overview

Imagine Pediatrics is a healthcare provider focused on delivering high-quality pediatric care. The organization emphasizes a patient-centered approach, ensuring that children receive comprehensive and compassionate medical attention.

## Company History

Imagine Pediatrics was founded with the mission to provide exceptional healthcare services to children and their families. The organization has grown over the years, establishing a reputation for excellence in pediatric care.

## Services

Imagine Pediatrics offers a range of services designed to meet the diverse needs of children, including:

- Routine check-ups and wellness visits
- Immunizations
- Management of chronic conditions
- Behavioral health services
- Nutritional counseling

## Products

While the primary focus is on healthcare services, Imagine Pediatrics may also provide educational materials and resources for parents to support their children's health and development.

## Customers

The primary customers of Imagine Pediatrics are children and their families, who seek reliable and compassionate healthcare services. The organization aims to build long-term relationships with its patients, ensuring continuity of care.

## Leadership Team

The leadership team at Imagine Pediatrics consists of experienced healthcare professionals dedicated to improving pediatric health outcomes. They are committed to fostering a supportive and collaborative environment for both staff and patients.

## Culture

Imagine Pediatrics promotes a culture of empathy, respect, and teamwork. The organization values open communication and strives to create a welcoming atmosphere for families, ensuring that every child feels safe and cared for during their visits.

For more information, visit [Imagine Pediatrics](https://verity.imaginepediatrics.org/mobile/imaginemobile.html).

reviews.cons: None to report right now
reviews.pros:
Awesome place to work at
Flexible work shifts
Competitive pay

reviews.cons:
Startup , constant change and micromanaging
Members don’t even know they have this service so it’s not being used . 

My role was not fully set when I got hired . I got hired in December of 24 and was told my role wouldn’t start until January 25. Jan came around and there was no work for us to do . They had us helping nurses schedule visits but sometimes it was hard to get a hold of caregivers . I was told I was going to get referrals but ended up having to find my own referrals which was hard cause again it’s hard to get a hold of the caregivers. When they did answers they didn’t know where I was calling from or just declined . I got fired for not having high productivity. 
Daily team meeting, supervisor checking in on you all day . It was easy but boring & overwhelming trying to find people to actually use the services.
reviews.pros: Mission to help medically complex kids

reviews.advice: "Put the children" not the dollar first as you preach in your motto.
reviews.cons: Management and leadership are not accountable with answers to challenges. The questions are always asked just to pretend that they are busy to follow up or have "dropped the ball" on. Long hours working as a telemarketer level job just to get everyone with Medicaid benefits to enroll. The patients' usual pediatricians and providers are upset when the coordinators call to get medical records without any relationship.
reviews.pros: Free coffee machine and name of the company is inviting.

reviews.advice: Be transparent and listen to your people. Always put the patient (customer) at the forefront.
reviews.cons: It’s new and young. Ramping quickly to be acquired. Make the money while feeling good about making the impact.
reviews.pros: Passionate people, great mission, eager leadership who wants to do the right thing.
reviews.summary: Work to do and getting it done

reviews.cons:
- Growing pains. The company has grown really fast. Sometimes lines of communication aren't super clear. Sometimes it feels like there are too many chefs in the kitchen. Swim lanes can be a little unclear. 
- Can feel isolating sometimes if you're working remotely
- Occasionally feel a bit removed from what the leadership cares about/is working on
reviews.pros:
- Mission-driven org; I think everyone here cares about helping sick kids even when there's disagreements about the best way to go about that. 
- Meaningful work-- I think we're positively impacting the lives of medically complex kids who might not have access to traditional forms of care. It's easy to get out of bed in the morning and do your job.
reviews.summary: Most rewarding job I've ever had

reviews.advice: Get your head out of the sand and start to recognize your employees who are dedicated. Treat people with kindness and respect.
reviews.cons: Leadership buries their head in the sand and acts as if everything is wonderful. They hire people and put them in leadership roles that have no idea how to do their job or the jobs of their reports. Leadership is never around or available. They treat people horribly but act on meetings as if they value their employees but they clearly don’t.
reviews.pros: The mission and services this company provides is amazing

reviews.advice:
Share more about venues for employee growth and development
Better communication across markets
reviews.cons:
High growth start up culture with a lot of change
Day to day changes in the markets 
Growing pains
reviews.pros:
Strong clinician leadership and a lot of growth
Really great patient outcomes and opportunities
Improving access to care for children on Medicaid
Highly Mission and Values Driven

reviews.advice: I would be clearer on longterm objectives and better communication with your employees
reviews.cons: -There are a lot of changes but is expected with being a newer company
reviews.pros:
-Work life balance
-The mission
-Inclusion (feeling valued)

reviews.cons:
Startup culture is great and constant changes get exhausting. 
Because so much is still being figured out, there is almost too many things at time. 
Does feel like a call center at times.
reviews.pros:
Being part of a company that is finally fixing the problem for children with medical complexities on Medicaid feels good to be apart of! 
Truly live by the values. 
The Medical teams can really do what's best for the patients. You're hands aren't tied to be the best nurse. 
Opportunities for growth, learning and meeting all levels of the org.
Isn't boring, constantly changing.
Addressing pay, bonuses to help with increased living expenses.
They put in the work to figure out how to make it easier for the next teams in Imagine. Like clear policies and procedures for the medical teams. 
It seems like the different teams are constantly addressing how to be better for the teams and the patients.

reviews.cons: The cons for this role is the lack of supportive management created a substantial barrier to fully realizing the potential for innovation and creativity. It was micro-managing, manipulative, and full of deceitful lies. There is no room to grow as a professional here due to the lack of engagement from the clients. At one point, it almost started to feel like a call center with clients who never answered the phone. If you want to grow as a social worker with supportive management, this company may not be the best fit for you. There are many more cons to say including the lack of diversity (rarely any POC on the leadership/ board team). If you search for poor starter-up company stories, this company will most likely be there.
reviews.pros: This review will be honest and transparent as possible. First, the flexibility to work from home has allowed for a better work-life balance. Another pro is that the team in the office provided free lunches most time. Since it is a start-up company, there is room for employees to bring new ideas to the table in different departments. (only if you have supportive management)

reviews.advice: Listen before there is a lawsuit.
reviews.cons: HR does shady stuff and ignores complaints, recruiters will say anything to bring you in, they fire people randomly.
reviews.pros: The supervisor of this department has some odd immunity. Despite over five complaints, she continues to be the manager of the department and terrorizes people. She has horrible management skills and will attempt to blame you for all of the mistakes of the department. The company fired multiple people and cut salaries to force individuals to quit. This position is not stable and the manager micromanages in a horrific way.

reviews.cons: We are in the build phase of our business which creates a lot of internal change.
reviews.pros:
The mission and values are palpable.
Patient-centered care is a top priority across the organization.

reviews.cons: Sometime I want to see the patients in person
reviews.pros:
The mission here is patient centered!
Great leadership team!
Awesome benefits!
Work from home options

reviews.cons: This company is very shady. They try to fire people when there are budget cuts. They will not work with you on any personal issues. Many employees quit or are randomly fired one day. There is no stability and management is horrific. Management is terrible, micromanage you, gaslight you, and belittle your ideas. The recruiters are untruthful. If you want to work for an agency that will fire you at any minute, work here. There is no room for growth, do not believe recruiters
reviews.pros: The mission and values of earning trust and children first, despite them not aligning that with the way they treat employees

reviews.advice: Show the compassion you’d like to show the community to your employees as well
reviews.cons: Management is microagressive and at some points racist. The level of gaslighting is terrible. They try to push people out whenever they want to save money. There is no diversity whatsoever. They love to talk about being supportive to their employees but it’s all a performance.
reviews.pros: the org mission is great
reviews.summary: Terrible company that will most likely fail

reviews.cons: Constantly changing with poor communication from leadership
reviews.pros: Strong Company with strong mission

reviews.cons: Typical startup headaches requires employees to be flexible
reviews.pros: Leadership is supportive and engaged, org has a strong mission based culture and drive

reviews.cons: Toxic culture and no one stays loner than 6 months.

reviews.cons: No cons in working for this company in my honest opinion

reviews.pros: Passionate people, great mission, eager leadership who wants to do the right thing.
reviews.summary: Work to do and getting it done

reviews.advice: "Put the children" not the dollar first as you preach in your motto.
reviews.cons: Management and leadership are not accountable with answers to challenges. The questions are always asked just to pretend that they are busy to follow up or have "dropped the ball" on. Long hours working as a telemarketer level job just to get everyone with Medicaid benefits to enroll. The patients' usual pediatricians and providers are upset when the coordinators call to get medical records without any relationship.
reviews.pros: Free coffee machine and name of the company is inviting.

reviews.cons: None to report right now
reviews.pros:
Awesome place to work at
Flexible work shifts
Competitive pay

reviews.cons:
Startup , constant change and micromanaging
Members don’t even know they have this service so it’s not being used . 

My role was not fully set when I got hired . I got hired in December of 24 and was told my role wouldn’t start until January 25. Jan came around and there was no work for us to do . They had us helping nurses schedule visits but sometimes it was hard to get a hold of caregivers . I was told I was going to get referrals but ended up having to find my own referrals which was hard cause again it’s hard to get a hold of the caregivers. When they did answers they didn’t know where I was calling from or just declined . I got fired for not having high productivity. 
Daily team meeting, supervisor checking in on you all day . It was easy but boring & overwhelming trying to find people to actually use the services.
reviews.pros: Mission to help medically complex kids

# Employee Sentiments

## Positive Sentiments

### Reasons Employees Like Working for Imagine Pediatrics

- "Amazing company" [(Customer Engagement Specialist, Glassdoor, 2024-01-09)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW83194481.htm)
- "Great mission, good work life balance, Remote first" [(Manager, Glassdoor, 2024-01-25)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW83734354.htm)
- "Being part of a company that is finally fixing the problem for children with medical complexities on Medicaid feels good to be a part of!" [(Health Services Manager, Glassdoor, 2024-04-17)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW86424627.htm)
- "The mission here is patient-centered! Great leadership team! Awesome benefits! Work from home options" [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2024-08-16)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW90159962.htm)
- "Strong clinician leadership and a lot of growth. Really great patient outcomes and opportunities" [(Licensed Mental Health Psychotherapist, Glassdoor, 2024-09-26)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW91393825.htm)

### Specific Details About Benefits

- "Awesome place to work at, Flexible work shifts, Competitive pay" [(Care Team Assistant, Glassdoor, 2025-03-05)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW95567501.htm)
- "Addressing pay, bonuses to help with increased living expenses" [(Health Services Manager, Glassdoor, 2024-04-17)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW86424627.htm)

## Negative Sentiments

### Reasons Employees Dislike Working for Imagine Pediatrics

- "This company is very shady. They try to fire people when there are budget cuts... management is horrific." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2024-03-03)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW84961585.htm)
- "Toxic culture and no one stays longer than 6 months." [(Social Worker/Case Manager, Glassdoor, 2024-03-11)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW85232031.htm)
- "Management is microaggressive and at some points racist. The level of gaslighting is terrible." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2024-04-23)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW86622435.htm)
- "Leadership buries their head in the sand and acts as if everything is wonderful." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2024-09-26)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW91373739.htm)

### Key Events or Changes in the Company

- "Rapid change, communication from exec team isn't great" [(Manager, Glassdoor, 2024-01-25)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW83734354.htm)
- "Growing pains. The company has grown really fast." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2024-09-06)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW90788867.htm)

## Advice to Management

- "Management is doing great and continues to do amazing" [(Customer Engagement Specialist, Glassdoor, 2024-01-09)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW83194481.htm)
- "Show the compassion you’d like to show the community to your employees as well" [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2024-04-23)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW86622435.htm)
- "Be transparent and listen to your people. Always put the patient (customer) at the forefront." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2024-12-06)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Imagine-Pediatrics-RVW93470220.htm)

news_result:
# [The Value of Engaged Caregivers in Improving Outcomes for Children with Special Health Care Needs on 2025-01-24](https://www.imaginepediatrics.org/white-paper/the-value-of-engaged-caregivers-in-improving-outcomes-for-children-with-special-health-care-needs/)
Jan 24, 2025 | Taylor Beery, Chief Innovation and Administration Officer & Co-Founder, Alison Curfman, M.D. Co-Founder

The Value of Engaged Caregivers in Improving Outcomes for Children with Special Health Care Needs

Executive Summary

Children with special health care needs (CSHCN) represent a significant population requiring comprehensive, coordinated care to achieve optimal health outcomes. This position statement outlines the critical role of engaged caregivers as part of the healthcare workforce and essential to improving health outcomes, expanding access to care, and reducing overall healthcare costs for CSHCN.

Background

Nearly 14.5 million children in the United States have special health care needs, and these children account for 50% of pediatric healthcare spending.1

These children face a fragmented, uncoordinated system of care that creates significant challenges, including:

Complex Care Coordination: Children require management across multiple specialists and providers, yet 21.8% of families with Medicaid-covered CSHCN report needing extra help coordinating care. Among these families, 23.1% never receive the assistance they need.²

Access Barriers: While these children require consistent medical care and specialized equipment:

Only 78.1% have a consistent healthcare provider

36.9% report emergency department visits (compared to 20.9% with private insurance)

17.6% cannot access needed mental health treatment

10.5% experience difficulties obtaining necessary referrals

35.9% report problems getting appointments²

Integration Challenges: Children require coordinated medical and behavioral health care, along with support for social determinants of health (SDOH), yet more than one-third of families report barriers to accessing these integrated services.²

This fragmentation results in measurable impacts on both health outcomes and family well-being, with 35.9% of Medicaid-covered CSHCN families reporting cost-related barriers to receiving needed services.²

This fragmentation in care delivery results in suboptimal outcomes, increased healthcare utilization, and significant emotional, mental, and financial burden on caregivers who must coordinate complex daily care needs across multiple providers and systems.3

‍Evidence Supporting Caregiver Engagement

In pediatrics, a growing body of research demonstrates the significant impact of engaged, educated, and supported caregivers on health outcomes and healthcare costs for children with special health care needs. Literature shows that family-centered care approaches are associated with improved adherence to treatment plans, better care coordination, and reduced healthcare utilization.4 The evidence consistently demonstrates that when caregivers are properly supported and engaged, both outcomes and costs improve across age groups and conditions.5

Evidence-Based Policy Impact

CMS Innovation Center Demonstrations

The Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (CMMI) has launched several initiatives that demonstrate the value of family-centered care models and caregiver engagement:

Integrated Care for Kids (InCK) Model

The InCK Model represents CMMI’s comprehensive approach to pediatric care transformation.6 Key components include:

Alternative payment models that support family-centered care coordination

Integration of physical and behavioral health care with social services

Emphasis on early identification and prevention

Required family engagement at both the individual care and program governance levels

State Innovation Models (SIM) initiative

The SIM Initiative has supported states in developing comprehensive healthcare transformation plans that include:

Implementation of pediatric-focused alternative payment models

Development of family navigation programs

Integration of community health workers into care teams

Creation of shared savings arrangements that incentivize family engagement

State Medicaid Innovation Programs

Several state Medicaid programs have pioneered successful family support initiatives:

California’s Health Homes for Children program demonstrated a 25% reduction in inpatient stays when implementing comprehensive family support services7

Texas’s STAR Kids program reported improved medication adherence and reduced emergency department utilization through family-centered care coordination8

Wisconsin Medicaid created a targeted case management model for children with medical complexity, enabling sustainable care programs with high family satisfaction9

These state initiatives have provided valuable evidence for scaling family-centered care models nationally.

American Academy of Pediatrics Guidelines

The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) clinical report underscores the importance of a coordinated approach to home care for children with complex health care needs.10 The report emphasizes establishing a medical home, providing comprehensive caregiver training, and supporting families to optimize children’s health and minimize hospitalizations through family-centered, interdisciplinary care.

Real-World Innovation and Outcomes

Imagine Pediatrics is a tech-enabled medical group that delivers 24/7 virtual and in-home care to children with special health care needs. Through value-based Medicaid contracts, the multidisciplinary, pediatrician-led team works in partnership with providers, caregivers, community resources, and health plans to expand patient access to fully integrated medical, behavioral, and social care at home. This innovative model recognizes that engaged caregivers drive better outcomes, placing them at the heart of the care delivery system and equipping them with comprehensive wraparound services to support their children’s complex health needs. Imagine Pediatrics does not replace a child’s existing care team or medical home. Instead, they coordinate with providers and partners to ensure continuous access to acute and longitudinal value-based care, so children and their caregivers can spend less unnecessary time in the hospital and more time safe at home and in their communities.

Key highlights of the program include:

24/7 access to virtual and in-home pediatric care services

Integrated medical, behavioral, and social care

Technology-enabled care coordination and family communication tools

Dedicated caregiver support, including training and individualized resources

Comprehensive support addressing social determinants of health (SDOH) and navigation of a complex and fragmented healthcare environment

Coordination and collaboration with the care delivery ecosystem to ensure all are focused on delivering whole-person, fully informed care

Population health data analytics measured through patient-centered digital, virtual, and in-home services and integrated with claims-based utilization data

Results from this caregiver-centered approach demonstrate significant improvements in both outcomes and costs:

30,000+ attributed patient supported by model across 3 states

~ 10%+ Medical Cost Ratio reduction (percentage of insurance premium payments that are paid out to providers and facilities for medical services) to date (1st patient population launched on 1/1/23)

87+ Net Promoter Score of Patients/Caregivers

Prevention of more than 5,000 emergency and urgent care visits through timely primary interventions, of which 80% required no acute care visits in the following 30 days

These results validate the findings from AAP, CMMI, and state programs while demonstrating the scalability of comprehensive, caregiver-engaged models for CSHCN populations.

Policy Recommendations

Recognition of Caregiving as Essential Healthcare Workers

Align with AAP recommendations to formally recognize family caregiving as a critical component of healthcare delivery for CSHCN10

Ensure healthcare policies and programs formally recognize caregiving for CSHCN as essential work, including Medicaid work requirements, family medical leave policies, and employment protections

Implement standardized assessment tools to evaluate caregiver needs and support requirements

Support for Innovative Care Models

Design alternative payment models that align incentives for payers, providers, and families to promote meaningful caregiver engagement

Create shared savings arrangements that reward providers and payers for successful caregiver partnerships and improved outcomes

Support flexible care delivery options that respond to diverse family needs while maintaining cost-effectiveness

Support technology-enabled care coordination and communication between caregivers, providers, and payers

Integrate Community Health Workers and Family Navigators into care teams to bridge gaps between clinical care and family needs

Expanded Access to Support Services

Support telehealth and virtual care options to increase access and reduce barriers to care, including across state lines and into rural areas

Ensure coverage for comprehensive care coordination across medical, behavioral, and social services

Enable streamlined access to community-based support services and social resources

Reform licensing and credentialing requirements to expand the medical and behavioral workforce, particularly in underserved areas

Investment in Caregiver Resources

Fund comprehensive caregiver training and education programs that build skills and confidence in managing complex care needs

Support respite care services that prevent burnout and enable sustainable caregiving

Provide dedicated access to mental health and peer support programs for caregivers

Conclusion

The evidence clearly demonstrates that engaged caregivers are essential partners in achieving optimal health outcomes for children with special health care needs. By implementing policies and tools that recognize, support, and empower caregivers, we can improve care quality, reduce costs, and better serve this vulnerable population. This foundational shift in how we view and value caregivers is critical to building a more effective, equitable healthcare system for CSHCN.

This position statement represents the first in a series of policy publications examining critical issues affecting children with special health care needs and their caregivers. Future publications will explore specific policy proposals in greater detail.

References

# Comprehensive Report on Imagine Pediatrics

## Company Overview

Imagine Pediatrics is a Nashville-based healthcare company founded in 2022 by Taylor Beery, Zeena Johar, Meghan Haycraft, and Alison Curfman. The company operates as a virtual healthcare provider specifically catering to children with complex medical conditions, offering 24/7 virtual and in-home pediatric care. As of October 2023, Imagine Pediatrics has raised a total of $37.6 million in funding, with its latest funding round being a Series C completed on February 27, 2025 [(Tracxn, 2023-10-11)](https://tracxn.com/d/companies/imagine-pediatrics/__suYLZqgbd3LGJm7PXqubGnwtYxfMmJMAOKDXyYnbYHQ).

The company is positioned within a competitive landscape, ranked 27th among 107 active competitors, including notable names like Teladoc and Plushcare. Imagine Pediatrics aims to address the fragmented healthcare system that children with special health care needs (CSHCN) often face, providing integrated medical, behavioral, and social care [(Tracxn, 2023-10-11)](https://tracxn.com/d/companies/imagine-pediatrics/__suYLZqgbd3LGJm7PXqubGnwtYxfMmJMAOKDXyYnbYHQ).

## Product Overview

Imagine Pediatrics focuses on delivering comprehensive care for children with special health care needs through a tech-enabled model. The service includes:

- **24/7 access to virtual and in-home pediatric care services**
- **Integrated medical, behavioral, and social care**
- **Technology-enabled care coordination and family communication tools**
- **Dedicated caregiver support, including training and individualized resources**
- **Comprehensive support addressing social determinants of health (SDOH)**

This model emphasizes the importance of engaged caregivers in improving health outcomes and reducing healthcare costs for CSHCN [(Beery & Curfman, 2025-01-24)](https://www.imaginepediatrics.org/white-paper/the-value-of-engaged-caregivers-in-improving-outcomes-for-children-with-special-health-care-needs/).

## Key Metrics and Achievements

Imagine Pediatrics has achieved significant milestones since its inception:

- **30,000+ patients** attributed to its care model across three states.
- **10%+ reduction** in Medical Cost Ratio, indicating a decrease in the percentage of insurance premium payments allocated to medical services.
- **87+ Net Promoter Score** from patients and caregivers, reflecting high satisfaction levels.
- **Prevention of over 5,000 emergency and urgent care visits** through timely primary interventions, with 80% of these cases requiring no acute care visits in the following 30 days [(Beery & Curfman, 2025-01-24)](https://www.imaginepediatrics.org/white-paper/the-value-of-engaged-caregivers-in-improving-outcomes-for-children-with-special-health-care-needs/).

## Funding and Financials

Imagine Pediatrics has successfully raised $37.6 million in a single funding round, with Oak HC/FT as its institutional investor. The company is currently in the Series C stage, indicating a strong interest from investors in its innovative approach to pediatric care [(Tracxn, 2023-10-11)](https://tracxn.com/d/companies/imagine-pediatrics/__suYLZqgbd3LGJm7PXqubGnwtYxfMmJMAOKDXyYnbYHQ).

## Leadership and Vision

The leadership team includes co-founders Taylor Beery and Alison Curfman, who emphasize the critical role of engaged caregivers in the healthcare system. They advocate for policies that recognize caregiving as essential work and support innovative care models that promote caregiver engagement [(Beery & Curfman, 2025-01-24)](https://www.imaginepediatrics.org/white-paper/the-value-of-engaged-caregivers-in-improving-outcomes-for-children-with-special-health-care-needs/).

## Market Position and Competitors

Imagine Pediatrics operates in a competitive market with 107 active competitors. Its primary competitors include:

- **Teladoc**: A public company providing a platform for web and mobile-based video consultations with doctors.
- **Plushcare**: A telemedicine service for urgent care that has been acquired.
- **Firefly Health**: A virtual-first healthcare company offering primary care services at an affordable price.

Despite the competition, Imagine Pediatrics differentiates itself through its focus on children with complex medical needs and its commitment to caregiver engagement [(Tracxn, 2023-10-11)](https://tracxn.com/d/companies/imagine-pediatrics/__suYLZqgbd3LGJm7PXqubGnwtYxfMmJMAOKDXyYnbYHQ).

## Conclusion

Imagine Pediatrics is positioned as a leader in the virtual healthcare space for children with special health care needs. With a strong funding base, innovative care model, and a commitment to caregiver engagement, the company is well-equipped to address the challenges faced by CSHCN and their families. As it continues to grow, prospective candidates and investors may find significant opportunities in its mission to transform pediatric care.
